sections: It's one of those scary days on the web for journalists and publishers ‚Äî Google is rolling out a major new update. The Helpful Content update (I miss the days when Google gave major updates cutesy names like ‚ÄúPanda‚Äù or ‚ÄúHummingbird‚Äù) started rolling out this morning, and will take around two weeks to fully implement.
I've written some initial thoughts about
, and what to watch, and will write more about it when we know more about how it's impacting publishers.

Do bear in mind that we won't know its true impact for some weeks, because Google will be constantly tweaking it as it rolls it out. These sorts of updates always have some unexpected side-effects that the search giant will be trying to correct as quickly as possible. That might be why they've chosen to roll it out in what's the dog days of summer for many of us in the English-speaking world.  By the time traffic picks up again in the autumn, they should have it sorted and working well.
In the meantime, be slightly sceptical of advice that's too detailed. Most people bashing out their hot takes are just guessing, and a guess written in an authoritative tone is still a guess.
Here's the tl;dr of the helpful content update for you:
If you've been writing articles that are based on reader need, you'll be fine (eventually)
If you've been targeting intents or keywords where there's no useful information to deliver yet (
What we know about the GoPro Hero 11
, for example: the answer is ‚Äúnothing yet‚Äù, bar a few guesses), then you might be hit, and need to watch your analytics closely.

If you see an impact, but don't think you're guilty of that sort of SEO-first strategy, don't panic ‚Äî Google will be tweaking this update for some months to come, so expect some instability in your search traffic.

Imagine that Twitter is a city whose corrupt government and potholed streets are pushing residents out. Slowly you‚Äôll start to see more ‚Äúfor rent‚Äù and ‚Äúwe‚Äôve moved‚Äù signs in shop windows. As city workers leave and budgets are slashed, the potholes will get worse.
